p.s: In the first few lines (ll. 1-9) the speaker welcomes everybody, especially Glasgow and Scotland (l. 1).
He refers to a known artist James Bond (l. 2)and explains his films (l. 3).
While refering to James Bond he uses a metaphorical words: red digital clock (l. 4) which end humans life as they know it.
It's a metaphoremetaphor for the left time we have.
If the clock stops ticking our life will end and our world will be completely destroyed.
He uses the metaphoric language to create a picture of our running out of time situation in the listeners mind and triggers with associations.
After explaining the films, he describes the climate change as a tragedy like James Bond movies (l. 6).
The temperature of the planet raises with a speed and apruptned which is man-made (l. 8).
In this way he explains the tragedy while using a personification which shows the impat of our man-made actions.
In the following paragraph (ll. 10-15), he reviews to the Copenhagen meeting 11 years ago (l. 10) where the world already had climate change as a problem.
Five years later they met again in Paris, where they talked about the problem (ll. 11f).
He explains the idea of rising the temperature to 1.5 degrees while using the words blah, blah, blah a use of phonetic alphabets and alliteration.
Those words become more memorable and show exactly the opinion of Johnson that those promises are ridiculous.
But in Glasgow they need to face the problem and not be ridiculous (l. 14f).
He accumulateaccumulates the words coal, cars, cash and trees (l. 16) while accumulating those words he includes the different groups which are effectedaffected by climate change.
While giving dates 200 years (l. 15), he explains how long climate change was ignored.

He plays with time, after explaining those years he goes back to nowaday (l. 20) in this way the listener can be able to memorize the importance of time, and the importance of changing the situation, now.
He explains in comprahisioncomparison the way they should not do it.

He refers to material ways to save the world with money (l. 22) but those material ways mean nothing Boris Johnson uses an antithesis between money and friends (ll. 13f), and shows how importanteimportant it is to work together while not using money, but funds we have in development assitenceassistance (l. 25).
The working together means more than money.

He explains also how they need to do it (ll. 25ff), which shows his knownledgeknowledge and that he does not only make promises, he has an idea and his idea functionatefunctions as we can see in Saudi Arabia (l. 29).
The following paragraph (l. 30) begins with inclusive language we (l. 30), the listeners can identify with the speakers idea of stopping climate change.
Furthermore he directly adresses to the fellow leaders (l. 31), in this way the fellow leaders will listen to his following explantationexplanation (l. 32).

He climax the anounce of people (ll. 33ff), firstly he referesrefers to crowds of young people, after this he describsedescribes the billions of people how are watching them and in the end he refers to half of the population.
This climax pointpoints out the importance of changing climate change and how many people actually are effectedaffected by the problem.
He explains his personal feeligns, mindset (l. 35) and fears and his future plans to become 94 years old (l. 36), and connects his idea iwth the ellipsis: But you never know (l. 36).
Which shows the essential issue, that the world can collapse and that we need to do a lot to stop climate change.
After expressing his own mindset and feeling he talks about the unborn children (l. 37).
While refering to the unborn children, he becomes emotionally and servers emphasis to the listener.
The listener can identify with feelings, in this way the speaker can achieve his goal, because if we won't do something against it, they will not forgive us (l. 39).
He also uses the stylistic devices, hyperbol (l. 44), which makes clear how many children are effectedaffected by our acting.
At the end of his speech he uses the stylistic device allusion (l. 47).
In this way he looks back to his introduction.
While refering to James Bond he can point out similarities and emphasizes the importance.
He uses the symbolic bomb in this way the listener are confronted with the speed and rapid change.
We need to do now something against it, if we do not do something against it, if we do not do something against it the bomb will explode and our planet will be destroyed.
